title: Cloth for woman's veil (Telia dupatta) or man's waist wrap (Telia lungi)
marks:
Inscription

at one corner, in black: [31]
text: This cotton ikat fabric is from an unused stockpile of similar <I>telia<I> cloth - so-called because the traditional dyeing process involved treating the threads with sesame oil (<I>tel<I>).  Produced in the southeast Indian coastal town of Chirala, <I>telia<I> cloth found a ready market in Hyderabad, the area's main trade center.  The fabric, often decorated with white embroidery, made an attractive head covering for women.  Men wore it plain as a waist wrap.
description: maroon borders with cream-colored stripes and plaids in intersecting striped areas; central black ground section with cream checks, and red and cream ikat-pattern designs; sized/starched
creditline: Gift of Richard L. Simmons in memory of Roberta Grodberg Simmons
